Study: Interrupting Endocrine Therapy to Attempt Pregnancy after Breast Cancer. (International Breast Cancer Study Group) , Partridge et al., NEJM, 2023/05/03
Conclusion: Temporary interruption of endocrine therapy to attempt pregnancy did not confer a greater short-term risk of breast cancer events than that in the external control cohort.
Primary Outcome: Number of breast cancer events
Results for the Primary Outcome: 8.9% (95% CI, 6.3 to 11.6) in the treatment-interruption group and 9.2% (95% CI, 7.6 to 10.8) in the control cohort
Comparator: Treatment-interruption group and external control cohort

Study: Fifteen-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Prostate Cancer. (ProtecT Study Group) , Hamdy et al., NEJM, 2023/03/13
Conclusion: Prostate cancer-specific mortality was low regardless of the treatment assigned.
Primary Outcome: Death from Prostate Cancer
Results for the Primary Outcome: 17 (3.1%) in the active-monitoring group, 12 (2.2%) in the prostatectomy group, and 16 (2.9%) in the radiotherapy group (P = 0.53 for the overall comparison).

Study: Trifluridine-Tipiracil and Bevacizumab in Refractory Metastatic Colorectal Cancer. (SUNLIGHT) , Prager et al., NEJM, 2023/05/03
Conclusion: Treatment with FTD-TPI plus bevacizumab resulted in longer overall survival than FTD-TPI alone.
Primary Outcome: Overall Survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival was 10.8 months in the combination group and 7.5 months in the FTD-TPI group (hazard ratio for death, 0.61; 95% CI, 0.49 to 0.77; P<0.001)
Comparator: FTD-TPI plus bevacizumab (combination group) or FTD-TPI alone (FTD-TPI group)

Study: Blinatumomab Added to Chemotherapy in Infant Lymphoblastic Leukemia., van der Sluis et al., NEJM, 2023/04/26
Conclusion: Blinatumomab added to Interfant-06 chemotherapy appeared to be safe and had a high level of efficacy in infants with newly diagnosed KMT2A-rearranged ALL as compared with historical controls from the Interfant-06 trial.
Primary Outcome: Clinically relevant toxic effects
Results for the Primary Outcome: No toxic effects meeting the definition of the primary end point occurred
Comparator: Blinatumomab added to Interfant-06 chemotherapy vs. Interfant-06 trial

Study: Bivalent Prefusion F Vaccine in Pregnancy to Prevent RSV Illness in Infants. (MATISSE) , Kampmann et al., NEJM, 2023/04/05
Conclusion: Vaccine administered during pregnancy was effective against medically attended severe RSV-associated lower respiratory tract illness in infants, and no safety concerns were identified.
Primary Outcome: Medically attended severe RSV-associated lower respiratory tract illness in infants within 90, 120, 150, and 180 days after birth
Results for the Primary Outcome: Vaccine efficacy of 81.8% (99.5% CI, 40.6 to 96.3) at 90 days, 69.4% (97.58% CI, 44.3 to 84.1) at later intervals

Study: Panitumumab vs Bevacizumab Added to Standard First-line Chemotherapy and Overall Survival Among Patients With RAS Wild-type, Left-Sided Metastatic Colorectal Cancer: A Randomized Clinical Trial., Watanabe et al., JAMA, 2023/04/18
Conclusion: Adding panitumumab to standard first-line chemotherapy significantly improved overall survival in those with left-sided tumors and in the overall population.
Primary Outcome: Overall survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival was 37.9 months with panitumumab vs 34.3 months with bevacizumab in participants with left-sided tumors (hazard ratio [HR] for death, 0.82; 95.798% CI, 0.68-0.99; P = .03) and 36.2 vs 31.3 months, respectively, in the overall population (HR, 0.84; 95% CI, 0.72-0.98; P = .03).

Study: Efficacy and safety of fitusiran prophylaxis in people with haemophilia A or haemophilia B with inhibitors (ATLAS-INH): a multicentre, open-label, randomised phase 3 trial., Young et al., Lancet, 2023/03/29
Conclusion: Fitusiran prophylaxis resulted in statistically significant reductions in annualized bleeding rate in participants with hemophilia A or hemophilia B with inhibitors, with two-thirds of participants having zero bleeds.
Primary Outcome: Mean annualized bleeding rate
Results for the Primary Outcome: Fitusiran prophylaxis group (1.7 [95% CI 1.0-2.7]) vs. bypassing agents on-demand group (18.1 [10.6-30.8]), corresponding to a 90.8% (95% CI 80.8-95.6) reduction in annualized bleeding rate in favor of fitusiran prophylaxis (p<0.0001)
Comparator: Fitusiran prophylaxis group vs. bypassing agents on-demand group

Study: Fezolinetant for treatment of moderate-to-severe vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause (SKYLIGHT 1): a phase 3 randomised controlled study., Lederman et al., Lancet, 2023/03/16
Conclusion: Data support the clinical use of fezolinetant as a non-hormonal treatment for vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause
Primary Outcome: Mean change in frequency and severity of vasomotor symptoms from baseline to weeks 4 and 12
Results for the Primary Outcome: Fexolinetant 30 mg and 45 mg significantly reduced the frequency and severity of vasomotor symptoms at weeks 4 and 12 compared to placebo

Study: Effect of Induction Therapy With Olamkicept vs Placebo on Clinical Response in Patients With Active Ulcerative Colitis: A Randomized Clinical Trial., Zhang et al., JAMA, 2023/03/07
Primary Outcome: 58.6% of patients receiving olamkicept 600 mg and 43.3% of patients receiving olamkicept 300 mg achieved clinical response at week 12 compared with 34.5% of patients receiving placebo
Results for the Primary Outcome: Olamkicept 600 mg was more effective than placebo in achieving clinical response at 12 weeks for patients with active ulcerative colitis.
Blinding: Clinical response at week 12 (defined as >=3 and >=30% decrease from baseline total Mayo score; range, 0-12 [worst] with >=1 decrease and <=1 in rectal bleeding [range, 0-3 {worst}])

Study: Adjuvant nivolumab plus ipilimumab versus placebo for localised renal cell carcinoma after nephrectomy (CheckMate 914): a double-blind, randomised, phase 3 trial., Motzer et al., Lancet, 2023/02/12
Conclusion: Adjuvant therapy with nivolumab plus ipilimumab did not improve disease-free survival versus placebo in patients with localised renal cell carcinoma at high risk of recurrence after nephrectomy.
Primary Outcome: Disease-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median disease-free survival was not reached in the nivolumab plus ipilimumab group and was 50*7 months (95% CI 48*1 to not estimable) in the placebo group (hazard ratio 0*92, 95% CI 0*71-1*19; p=0*53).

Study: Effect of Thromboprophylaxis on Clinical Outcomes After COVID-19 Hospitalization. (ACTIV-4C) , Wang et al., Annals of internal medicine, 2023/03/20
Conclusion: The incidence of death or thromboembolism was low in this cohort of patients discharged after hospitalization with COVID-19
Primary Outcome: 30-day composite of death, arterial thromboembolism, and venous thromboembolism
Results for the Primary Outcome: Incidence of the primary end point was 2.13% (95% CI, 1.14 to 3.62) in the apixaban group and 2.31% (CI, 1.27 to 3.84) in the placebo group

Study: Ide-cel or Standard Regimens in Relapsed and Refractory Multiple Myeloma., Rodriguez-Otero et al., NEJM, 2023/02/10
Conclusion: Ide-cel therapy significantly prolonged progression-free survival and improved response as compared with standard regimens in patients with triple-class-exposed relapsed and refractory multiple myeloma who had received two to four regimens previously.
Primary Outcome: Progression-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median progression-free survival was 13.3 months in the ide-cel group, as compared with 4.4 months in the standard-regimen group (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.49; 95% confidence interval, 0.38 to 0.65; P<0.001).

Study: Hyperfractionation compared with standard fractionation in intensity-modulated radiotherapy for patients with locally advanced recurrent nasopharyngeal carcinoma: a multicentre, randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial., You et al., Lancet, 2023/02/26
Conclusion: Hyperfractionated intensity-modulated radiotherapy could significantly decrease the rate of severe late complications and improve overall survival among patients with locally advanced recurrent nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
Primary Outcome: Incidence of severe late complications (grade 3 or worse) and overall survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Significantly lower incidence of grade 3 or worse late radiation-induced toxicity in the hyperfractionation group (23 [34%] of 68 patients) vs the standard fractionation group (39 [57%] of 68 patients); 3-year overall survival in the hyperfractionation group (74*6% [95% CI 64*4 to 84*8]) vs the standard fractionation group (55*0% [43*4 to 66*6]); fewer grade 5 late complications in the hyperfractionation group (five [7%] nasal haemorrhage) than in the standard fractionation group (16 [24%])
Comparator: Hyperfractionation (65 Gy in 54 fractions, given twice daily with an interfractional time interval of at least 6 h) vs Standard Fractionation (60 Gy in 27 fractions, given once a day)

Study: Expectant Management or Early Ibuprofen for Patent Ductus Arteriosus. (BeNeDuctus Trial Investigators) , Hundscheid et al., NEJM, 2022/12/08
Conclusion: Expectant management for PDA in extremely premature infants was noninferior to early ibuprofen treatment with respect to necrotizing enterocolitis, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or death at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age.
Primary Outcome: necrotizing enterocolitis (Bell's stage IIa or higher), moderate to severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia, or death at 36 weeks' postmenstrual age
Results for the Primary Outcome: absolute risk difference of -17.2 percentage points (P<0.001 for noninferiority)
Comparator: expectant management vs. early ibuprofen treatment

Study: Two-Year Outcomes of Valoctocogene Roxaparvovec Therapy for Hemophilia A. (GENEr8-1 Trial Group) , Mahlangu et al., NEJM, 2023/02/22
Conclusion: Valoctocogene roxaparvovec therapy was effective in reducing bleeding events and had a safe profile at least 2 years after the gene transfer.
Primary Outcome: Change from baseline in the annualized rate of treated bleeding events at week 104 after receipt of the infusion
Results for the Primary Outcome: Mean annualized treated bleeding rate decreased by 84.5% from baseline (P<0.001)

Study: Nicotinamide for Skin-Cancer Chemoprevention in Transplant Recipients., Allen et al., NEJM, 2023/03/01
Conclusion: Oral nicotinamide therapy did not lead to lower numbers of keratinocyte cancers or actinic keratoses in immunosuppressed solid-organ transplant recipients.
Primary Outcome: Number of new keratinocyte cancers during the 12-month intervention period
Results for the Primary Outcome: 207 new keratinocyte cancers in the nicotinamide group and 210 in the placebo group (rate ratio, 1.0; 95% confidence interval, 0.8 to 1.3; P = 0.96)

Study: Gene Therapy with Etranacogene Dezaparvovec for Hemophilia B., Pipe et al., NEJM, 2023/02/22
Conclusion: Etranacogene dezaparvovec gene therapy was superior to prophylactic factor IX with respect to the annualized bleeding rate, and it had a favorable safety profile.
Primary Outcome: Annualized bleeding rate
Results for the Primary Outcome: Decreased from 4.19 to 1.51, rate ratio of 0.36 (95% Wald CI, 0.20 to 0.64; P<0.001)

Study: Neoadjuvant-Adjuvant or Adjuvant-Only Pembrolizumab in Advanced Melanoma., Patel et al., NEJM, 2023/03/01
Conclusion: Pembrolizumab given both before and after surgery increased event-free survival among patients with resectable stage III or IV melanoma compared to pembrolizumab given as adjuvant therapy alone.
Primary Outcome: Event-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Neoadjuvant-adjuvant group had significantly longer event-free survival than the adjuvant-only group (72% at 2 years vs. 49%)

Study: Rucaparib or Physician's Choice in Metastatic Prostate Cancer. (TRITON3) , Fizazi et al., NEJM, 2023/02/16
Conclusion: Rucaparib was found to be more effective than a control medication in prolonging imaging-based progression-free survival in patients with metastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer with a BRCA alteration.
Primary Outcome: Median Duration of Imaging-Based Progression-Free Survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: 11.2 months in the Rucaparib group vs. 6.4 months in the Control group (hazard ratio, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.36 to 0.69)

Study: Exercise for the Prevention of Anthracycline-Induced Functional Disability and Cardiac Dysfunction: The BREXIT Study., Foulkes et al., Circulation, 2022/11/07
Conclusion: Exercise Training (ExT) provided large, clinically meaningful benefits on functional disability and cardiac reserve in women with early-stage breast cancer undergoing anthracycline-based chemotherapy (AC).
Primary Outcome: Functional Disability
Results for the Primary Outcome: ExT attenuated functional disability at 4 months (odds ratio, 0.32 [95% CI, 0.11-0.94]; P=0.03) but not at 12 months (odds ratio, 0.27 [95% CI, 0.06-1.12]; P=0.07). In a per-protocol analysis, functional disability was prevented entirely at 12 months among participants adherent to ExT (ExT, 0% versus UC, 20%; P=0.005).

Study: Sotorasib versus docetaxel for previously treated non-small-cell lung cancer with KRASG12C mutation: a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial. (CodeBreaK 200 Investigators) , de Langen et al., Lancet, 2023/02/10
Conclusion: Sotorasib significantly increased progression-free survival and had a more favourable safety profile, compared with docetaxel, in patients with advanced NSCLC with the KRAS(G12C) mutation and who had been previously treated with other anticancer drugs.
Primary Outcome: Progression-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median progression-free survival 5.6 months (95% CI 4.3-7.8) for sotorasib vs 4.5 months (3.0-5.7) for docetaxel; hazard ratio 0.66 (0.51-0.86); p=0.0017

Study: Aspirin or Low-Molecular-Weight Heparin for Thromboprophylaxis after a Fracture. ((METRC)) , O'Toole et al., NEJM, 2023/01/18
Conclusion: Aspirin was noninferior to low-molecular-weight heparin in preventing death and was associated with low incidences of deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and low 90-day mortality.
Primary Outcome: Death from any cause at 90 days
Results for the Primary Outcome: Death occurred in 47 patients (0.78%) in the aspirin group and in 45 patients (0.73%) in the low-molecular-weight-heparin group (difference, 0.05 percentage points; 96.2% confidence interval, -0.27 to 0.38; P<0.001 for a noninferiority margin of 0.75 percentage points)

Study: Medial retropharyngeal nodal region sparing radiotherapy versus standard radiotherapy in patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma: open label, non-inferiority, multicentre, randomised, phase 3 trial., Mao et al., BMJ (Clinical research ed.), 2023/02/06
Conclusion: MRLN sparing radiotherapy showed non-inferiority in terms of risk of local relapse with fewer radiation related toxicity and improved patient reported outcomes in patients with non-metastatic nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
Primary Outcome: Three year local relapse-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: 95.3% vs. 95.5%, stratified hazard ratio 1.04 (95% confidence interval 0.51 to 2.12), P=0.95
Comparator: MRLN sparing radiotherapy group vs. standard radiotherapy group

Study: Adjuvant S-1 compared with observation in resected biliary tract cancer (JCOG1202, ASCOT): a multicentre, open-label, randomised, controlled, phase 3 trial. (Hepatobiliary and Pancreatic Oncology Group of the Japan Clinical Oncology Group ) , Nakachi et al., Lancet, 2023/01/21
Conclusion: Adjuvant S-1 could be considered a standard of care for resected biliary tract cancer in Asian patients.
Primary Outcome: Overall Survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: 3-year overall survival was 67.6% (95% CI 61.0-73.3%) in the observation group compared with 77.1% (70.9-82.1%) in the S-1 group (adjusted hazard ratio [HR] 0.69, 95% CI 0.51-0.94; one-sided p=0.0080)

Study: Momelotinib versus danazol in symptomatic patients with anaemia and myelofibrosis (MOMENTUM): results from an international, double-blind, randomised, controlled, phase 3 study. (MOMENTUM) , Verstovsek et al., Lancet, 2023/01/28
Conclusion: Treatment with momelotinib resulted in clinically significant improvements in myelofibrosis-associated symptoms, anaemia measures, and spleen response, with favourable safety.
Primary Outcome: Myelofibrosis Symptom Assessment Form (MFSAF) TSS response rate at week 24
Results for the Primary Outcome: 32 (25%) of 130 in the momelotinib group vs. 6 (9%) of 65 in the danazol group (proportion difference 16% [95% CI 6-26], p=0*0095)

Study: Zanubrutinib or Ibrutinib in Relapsed or Refractory Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia., Brown et al., NEJM, 2022/12/13
Conclusion: Patients with relapsed or refractory CLL or SLL who received zanubrutinib had longer progression-free survival and fewer cardiac adverse events than those who received ibrutinib.
Primary Outcome: Progression-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Zanubrutinib was superior to ibrutinib with respect to progression-free survival (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.65; 95% confidence interval, [CI], 0.49 to 0.86; P = 0.002)

Study: Lobar or Sublobar Resection for Peripheral Stage IA Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer., Altorki et al., NEJM, 2023/02/13
Conclusion: Sublobar resection is as effective as lobectomy in terms of disease-free survival for patients with peripheral NSCLC with a tumor size of 2 cm or less and pathologically confirmed node-negative disease in the hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes.
Primary Outcome: Disease-free survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Sublobar resection was not inferior to lobectomy with respect to disease-free survival (hazard ratio for disease recurrence or death, 1.01; 90% confidence interval [CI], 0.83 to 1.24). 5-year disease-free survival was 63.6% (95% CI, 57.9 to 68.8) after sublobar resection and 64.1% (95% CI, 58.5 to 69.0) after lobar resection.

Study: Efanesoctocog Alfa Prophylaxis for Patients with Severe Hemophilia A. (XTEND-1) , von Drygalski et al., NEJM, 2023/01/31
Conclusion: Once-weekly efanesoctocog alfa provided superior bleeding prevention to prestudy prophylaxis, normal to near-normal factor VIII activity, and improvements in physical health, pain, and joint health.
Primary Outcome: Mean annualized bleeding rate in Group A
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median annualized bleeding rate was 0 (interquartile range, 0 to 1.04); estimated mean annualized bleeding rate was 0.71 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.52 to 0.97); mean annualized bleeding rate decreased from 2.96 (95% CI, 2.00 to 4.37) to 0.69 (95% CI, 0.43 to 1.11) (P<0.001)
Comparator: Group A (once-weekly prophylaxis with efanesoctocog alfa) and Group B (on-demand treatment with efanesoctocog alfa)

Study: Effects of Dapagliflozin on Hospitalizations in Patients With Chronic Kidney Disease : A Post Hoc Analysis of DAPA-CKD., Schechter et al., Annals of internal medicine, 2022/12/05
Conclusion: Dapagliflozin reduced the risk for hospitalization for any cause in patients with CKD with and without type 2 diabetes.
Primary Outcome: Risk for hospitalization for any cause
Results for the Primary Outcome: Dapagliflozin reduced risk for a first hospitalization (hazard ratio, 0.84 [95% CI, 0.75 to 0.94]) and all hospitalizations or death (rate ratio, 0.79 [CI, 0.70 to 0.89])

Study: Sotorasib in KRAS p.G12C-Mutated Advanced Pancreatic Cancer., Strickler et al., NEJM, 2022/12/22
Conclusion: Sotorasib showed anticancer activity and had an acceptable safety profile in patients with KRAS p.G12C-mutated advanced pancreatic cancer who had received previous treatment.
Primary Outcome: Centrally confirmed objective response (defined as a complete or partial response)
Results for the Primary Outcome: 8 patients had a centrally confirmed objective response (21%; 95% CI, 10 to 37)

Study: Rezafungin versus caspofungin for treatment of candidaemia and invasive candidiasis (ReSTORE): a multicentre, double-blind, double-dummy, randomised phase 3 trial. (ReSTORE trial investigators) , Thompson et al., Lancet, 2022/11/28
Conclusion: Rezafungin was found to be as effective and safe as caspofungin for treating candidaemia and invasive candidiasis.
Primary Outcome: Global cure at day 14 (EMA) and 30-day all-cause mortality (FDA)
Results for the Primary Outcome: Rezafungin was non-inferior to caspofungin for the primary endpoints of day-14 global cure (EMA) and 30-day all-cause mortality (FDA).

Study: Adagrasib with or without Cetuximab in Colorectal Cancer with Mutated KRAS G12C., Janne et al., NEJM, 2022/06/03
Conclusion: Adagrasib showed clinical efficacy without new safety signals
Primary Outcome: Objective response assessed by blinded independent central review
Results for the Primary Outcome: 42.9% had a confirmed objective response; median duration of response was 8.5 months; median progression-free survival was 6.5 months; median overall survival was 12.6 months
Comparator: KRAS(G12C)-mutated NSCLC patients previously treated with platinum-based chemotherapy and anti-programmed death 1 or programmed death ligand 1 therapy
